Description: A jug of pale green-cream marl pottery, with a slightly convex base and convex sides. There is a distinct shoulder, from which the sides converge to a narrow neck, at one side of which is a loop-handle. The top of the neck is finished with a flared rim, which is slightly damaged. The jug has been reconstructed from fragments with some pieces missing. The exterior (and perhaps interior) is covered by a thin pale greenish slip.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", east annex (C), chamber 19
Curator's comments: No registration details are available before the transfer from GR, but the object must have come from the Egypt Exploration Fund excavation at Tell Dafana, directed by Flinders Petrie in 1886. The findspot number 19A scratched into the object near the base confirms this provenance.
Bibliographic references: Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.92, p.95, p.107, p.134, p.195, pl.37, p.219, pl.61)
